Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Identification Technology Research (CITeR) - UB Site

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Center for Identification Technology Research (CITeR)

1266183 SUNY at Buffalo; Venugopal Govindaraju

The proposed site, SUNY at Buffalo, requests funding to establish a partner site of the Center for Identification Research (CITeR) currently comprised of the Clarkson University (lead institution), West Virginia University and the University of Arizona as research partners.

The proposed site will advance the science of biometric technologies for both civilian and homeland security applications by integrating pattern recognition and machine learning algorithms with sensors technology. SUNY at Buffalo site will bring together faculty expertise, not only in core biometric modalities such as fingerprints and face recognition, and soft biometrics such as gender, age, mannerisms, and emotion, but also in related areas such as advanced computer vision, robotics, cryptography, and theoretical computer science that will allow CITeR to pursue research in the development of innovative biometric applications. CITeR affiliates will also benefit from being able to benchmark and assess the effectiveness of various hard and soft biometric technologies in real applications. The proposed site's faculty strength in Chemistry, Physics and Optics will also help CITeR pursue novel modulaties such as odor biometrics and better sensors to assist in identification technologies.

The proposed site will further CITeR's objective to serve as a comprehensive academic center serving the growing identification technology research, undergraduate and graduate education, and outreach needs of the public and private sectors. This will be accomplished by providing a mechanism for the funding of pooled interdisciplinary faculty and student talent to address the challenges in identification technology. Under the auspices of BEAM (Buffalo Area Engineering Awareness for Minorities) the proposed site plans to attract the participation of local high school and undergraduate students using innovative events built around biometrics applications that incorporate treasure hunts and other fun elements to educate and interest them in STEM areas. The faculty at SUNY Buffalo are members of the NSF-AGEP (The Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate) program whose goal is to significantly increase the number of underrepresented minorities obtaining graduate degrees in STEM areas. CITeR meetings will also serve as an excellent opportunity for students to interact with potential employers to understand challenges in the field.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Buffalo
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of CITeR as an I/UCRC is to serve an enabling role in the development of identity management systems through cross-cutting research of new technologies, the interdisciplinary training of scientists and engineers across its breadth, and the facilitation of the transfer of this technology to the private and government sectors.  CITeR?s research focus is human analytics, identity science, biometric analysis, and policy/privacy whereas the UB site?s focus is on novel, soft, and behavioral biometrics, biometric fusion of traditional modalities such as face, finger and iris as well as soft and behavioral biometrics.  CITeR affiliates (members) at the University at Buffalo in Phase I included Department of Homeland Security (S&T), National Security Agency, Qualcomm, Raytheon BBN Technologies, CUBRC, and Zoloz Inc.  Results of CITeR research include refereed publications, datasets released to researchers, intellectual property, public domain software tools and leadership role in building the technical community as well as placement of students within key firms and government agencies.  CITeR seeks to develop an advanced, comprehensive theoretical and analytical framework within which the performance of tools can be modeled, predicted, and tested. 

Intellectual Merit

The Technical Area for the Center of Identification Technology Research (CITeR) is Identity. Having a provable and verifiable identity is a prerequisite for an individual to function in modern society.  Your identity is what allows you to have a job, maintain a bank account, and drive a car.  Identity is also what allows society to be free and safe, as dangerous individuals can be excluded from the public, for instance through placing suspected terrorists on no-flight lists and by capturing known criminals.   In particular, CITeR is focused on providing technology for providing, confirming, and determining identity.  CITeR?s core research focuses on automated decisions surrounding the use of data collected from individuals and resting on firm pillars of trust, privacy, security, and reliability. 

Broader Impacts

CITeR faculty are actively engaged with outreach, recruitment, and retention programs at the University at Buffalo. Results have been disseminated to the biometrics community through publications in journals, conferences and workshops in the relevant areas.  Project results have been highlighted using outreach activities such as open houses and summer camps for high-school students under the BEAM (Buffalo-Area Engineering Awareness for Minorities) program which is a cooperative educational enrichment program that prepares inner city, minority, female and other under-represented students for careers in science, engineering, and technology.  Presentations were also made at other University outreach activities (workshops, science fair events) geared towards K-12 and other target communities to encourage STEM participation. The research into sophisticated finger test phantoms (fake fingers used to spoof systems) has also been used to spark interest in biometrics in many aspiring STEM students.  CITeR is active in outreach to K-12.  We hosted STEM outreach activities,  e.g., for 600 grade school students (from pre-K to 3rd grade) and for high school students concurrent with a CITeR meeting where affiliates participated on a panel on careers. 

Outcomes

Research results on a wide variety of problems in biometrics were published in conferences and journals. Datasets and software tools were released to other researchers through the website. In addition, CITeR hosted a webinar series with 8-10 lectures per semester. The results of this research are provided in regular webinars advertised to the CITeR community and beyond.  Lastly, CITeR, being an NSF I/UCRC, naturally meets some of the broader impacts including ?increased partnerships between academia, industry, and others? and ?increased economic competitiveness of the United States? with transition of research through center operations and licensing/start-up events.  In additional, CITeR?s focus on identification technology impacts ?improved national security? by meeting the research needs of DHS, FBI, and DoD.

Site specific examples of impact of CITeR research includes many publications, datasets and software tools.  A few outcomes are featured below.

Tools: 

(i) mBrain Password: An EEG-based User Authentication System for Mobile Devices:  A prototype was developed to show how brain waves could be used to authenticate users on a mobile platform.

(ii) Wardrobe Models for Long Term Re-Identification and Appearance Prediction: Tools were developed to use information learned by the system about a person?s wardrobe over a longitudinal time period and identify a person purely based on identifying the clothing worn by them. 

(iii) Microfluidic 3D Capillary Network Test Phantom for Subdermal Vascular Imaging: The test phantom possessed many of the subdermal physiological features and measurements seen within the human finger. Showing both arterial distention and compression, bone patterns, blood flow, vascular compliance features, and ultimately a functional 3D capillary network. This capillary network is the first of its kind creating an extremely realistic finger phantom that could be used to design protections against highly sophisticated spoofs.

Datasets:

(i) EEG dataset for EEG-based user authentication.

(ii) Face image dataset - for modeling camera height, camera distance, and pose.


Last Modified: 10/29/2019
Modified by: Srirangaraj Setlur

Images (1 of )
  • Modeling the wardrobe of individuals by identifying clothing items worn by them over a period of many days from video sequences and using that information for re-identifying people purely based on clothing as a soft biometric.
    University at Buffalo, SUNY
    Copyrighted
    Srirangaraj Setlur
    Wardrobe as a Soft Biometric for Re-identification
  • Left A finger test phantom. B) Ultrasonic image of the finger test phantom showing arterial tubing and bone structures. C and D) Capillary network imaged ultrasonically Right: An acoustically equivalent test phantom arm simulating, blood, bone, skin, fat, muscle tissue etc.
    University at Buffalo, SUNY
    Srirangaraj Setlur
    Biometric Test Phantoms
  • EEG-based User Authentication System on Mobile Devices - Users are authenticated purely based on unique brain responses to visual stimuli.
    University at Buffalo, SUNY
    Copyrighted
    Srirangaraj Setlur
    mBrainPassword
